thread.title: Art gallery forced to remove obscene Victorian photos
thread.title_full: Art gallery forced to remove obscene Victorian photos

title: Art gallery forced to remove obscene Victorian photos
text:
Share this article Share 'They thought they were obscene and bordered on pornographic but the images are nothing of the sort. 'There is nudity but I wouldn't even describe them as racy and they certainly aren't pornographic.' She said it is not known who the photographic works are by and said they were donated to the gallery by a local collector. However, after an overwhelming show of public support, the couple decided to reinstate the pieces - with a warning to visitors. The photographic works were donated to the gallery by a local collector and initially removed - before being reinstated after an overwhelming show of support from locals The nude boudoir photographs did not appeal to all tastes - with some describing them as 'disgusting and obscene' A group of female visitors demanded the six offending photos be withdrawn from the exhibition at the South Downs Heritage Centre in Hassocks, West Sussex Mrs Nee said: 'Obviously we didn't want to offend anyone visiting the exhibition so we took them down straight away. 'However, after consideration by the heritage centre the photos are going to be put back up - though we will put a notice up warning visitors there are photos which contain some nudity at the back of the exhibition.' The photographs were displayed alongside pieces by local sculptors and artists, as well as works by Sir William Russell Flint and John Yardley. After consideration by the heritage centre (pictured) the photos are going to be put back up - with a notice up warning visitors there are photos which contain some nudity at the back of the exhibition The photographs were displayed alongside pieces by local sculptors and artists, as well as works by Sir William Russell Flint and John Yardley Curator Martin Nee added: 'Before 1839, depictions of nudity generally consisted of paintings, drawings and engravings. 'Artists then began to use new photography techniques and technology as a new and exciting way to depict the nude form. 'The history of this art form is probably more interesting than the work itself to a lot of people. Obviously, it was not intended to cause offence.' Share or comment on this article 
Looks like the "mad pixelator" is having a day off ...
